cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S Government p^mted for the WartCabinet. January 1942.SECRET Copy"No;^.M; (42) v : - . m43th ^Conclusions. 'TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken to ; ;ensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 13 (42).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10, Downing Street,S'W.1, on Thursday, January 29, 1942, at 6 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (m the Chair).The Right. Hon C. R. Attlee, M.P,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon. Anthony Eden, M.P.,-Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. Lord Beaverbrook,Minister of Supply.The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood. M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood,M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer.The Rt. Hon. :Ernest J3evin, M.P.,Minister of Labour , and NationalService.The following were also present:The Right Hon. L. S. Amery, M.P.,Secretary of State for India and secretary of State for Burma.Sir Edward Bridges, Secretary.Contents.minute no. Subject. I'age1 China ............ ............ . ........ 68'2 The Far East .............................. 68Allied co-ordination.3 U.S.S.R............. .................... 68Soviet Trade Union Delegation to the United Kingdom.[23399] China.(previous reference:W.M. (42) 8thConclusions,Minute 1.)The Far East.allied co-ordination.(previous reference erence:W.M. (42) 12thConclusions.)1. The War Cabinet had a discussion about our relations with china, which is recorded in the Secretary's Standard File of WarCabinet Conclusions.2. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that hethought it would be of great advantage if the Prime Minister andhe could meet the Dutch Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary, and explain matters to them.The Prime Minister agreed that such a meeting should bearranged in the near future, probably on Sunday, 1st February.U.S.S.R.soviet trade UnionDelegationto the UnitedKingdom.(previous reference:W.M. (42) 7thConclusions.Minute 1.)3. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said thatthe Soviet Trade Union Delegation were not satisfied with thearrangements proposed for their return journey, namely, that four members of the delegation would be flown direct to Egypt, but thatthe others would have to go to Takoradi by sea and be flown thence.The party was unwilling to be separated. They were also anxious not to make the journey in a trade convoy by the Northern route.Sir Walter Citrine had urged that a cruiser should be put at their disposal.In discussion it was pointed out that it would be very difficultto make a cruiser available, but that it might be easier to providea large destroyer.The War Cabinet Expressed the hope that it might be found possible to makea destroyer available to take the Delegation back to Russia,and invited the Foreign Secretary to make representationsin this sense to the First Lord of the Admiralty.Great George Street, S.W. 1,January 29, 1942.
